item.description: [!info] This page does not exist (yet)!

item.title: action potential
item.description: When the membrane potential of a cell rapidly rises and falls Depolarization Na+ enters cell through sodium channel electric charge becomes positive (+30mV) Repolarization at +30mV, K+ leaves through potassium channel electric charge decreases below resting charge (-70mV) Hyperpolarization K+ channels close, [[sodium-potassium pump]] restores polarization to -70mV Action potential goes along [[axon]], jumps to other neurons through [[synapses]]

item.title: autonomic nervous system
item.description: sympathetic nervous system fight or flight response increase in heart rate, breathing blood to muscles Balance is important

item.title: axon
item.description: the cord in a [[neurons|neuron]] where electrical impulses travel [[myelin covering]] makes [[action potential]] jump, increases speed hundredfold (1m/s to 100m/s

item.title: brain
item.description: Two matter gray matter contains the body of neurons [!info] spinal cord → located inside brain → located outside

item.title: central nervous system
item.description: [[brain]] and [[spinal cord]]

item.title: cervix
item.description: connects the vagina and the body of uterus closed except during childbirth and [[menstruation]]

item.title: clitoris
item.description: [!info] This page does not exist (yet)!

item.title: cochlea
item.description: spirally coiled, filled with fluid receptors in the ear sense the movement of the fluid high frequencies on the base low frequencies on the bottom

item.title: corpus of uterus
item.description: Where the fetus develops mucous membrane during menstrual cycle

item.title: corpus spongiosum
item.description: creates the glans (end of penis) and is covered with foreskin richest in nerves (mechanoreceptors) circumcision → prevents infections, inflammations, and cancer

item.title: diabetes
item.description: diabetes low or missing insulin production carb, lipid, protein metabolism affected cells cannot access glucose → high blood sugar thirst, hunger, frequent urination, weight loss, blurry vision, fatigue, dry skin [[Type 1]]

item.title: Disorders of the Endocrine System
item.description: hormone imbalance → problems problems (infection, injury, tumor, feedback system, lack of iodine, genetics [[growth hormone disorders]] - grows too much or too little

item.title: ears
item.description: mechanoreceptors inside the [[cochlea]] Outer ear collects sound, ends in the [[eardrum]] middle ear has 3 bones ([[ossicles]]) connecting the eardrum and cochlea and intensify the vibration

item.title: epididymis
item.description: place of sperm maturation and storage back surface of testicles

item.title: eyes
item.description: several layers: [[vitreous body]] gives its shape the [[lens]] focuses the light onto [[photoreceptors]] by changing its shape ([[ciliary muscles]] make it flat of convex)

item.title: fallopian tubes
item.description: connect [[ovaries]] to [[uterus]] fertilization happens in the upper ⅓

item.title: goitre
item.description: big appetite but weight loss, high blood pressure, tachycardia, sweating, diarrhea, irritability, hyperactivity, bulging eyes [!important] There’s also hypothyroidism, which is the underproduction of thyroxine

item.title: gonads
item.description: produce sperm and ova ([[ovaries]] in females, [[testicles]] in males)

item.title: Grouping of reproductive organs
item.description: External reproductive organs Males [[penis]] [[scrotum]] Females [[vaginal opening]] [[labia]] [[clitoris]] Internal reproductive organs Males 2 [[testicles]] 2 [[epididymis]] 2 [[vas deferenses]] 2 [[seminal vesicles]] [[prostate gland]] Females 2 [[ovaries]] 2 [[fallopian tubes]] / uterine tubes [[uterus]] [[vagina]]

item.title: growth hormone
item.description: [[growth hormone]] growth hormone overproduction ([[hypophysis]]) acromegaly during adulthood growth hormone underproduction proportionally small body normal or higher intelligence dwarfism (<140cm)

item.title: Human nervous system
item.description: Functions sensory input information processing motor output [[neurons]] are its basic unit center for all mental activity _thought, learning, memory

item.title: Human reproductive system
item.description: [!important] Aim is to pass on characteristics with genes Differences between male-female Primary sexual characteristics reproductive organs Secondary sexual characteristics (result of sex hormones)

item.title: Human sense organs
item.description: responsible for perception, containing receptors information processed by the [[brain]] 5 sense organs [[eyes]] - photoreceptors [[ears]] - mechanoreceptors [[nose]] - chemoreceptors [[tongue]] - chemoreceptors [[skin]] - pain receptors, thermoreceptors, mechanoreceptors

item.title: hypophysis
item.description: Also called the pituaitary, it maintains appropriate environment in body

item.title: implantation
item.description: embryo adheres to the endometrium → digs itself in

item.title: labia
item.description: [!info] This page does not exist (yet)!

item.title: menstruation
item.description: makes pregnancy possible

item.title: myelin covering
item.description: made by glial cells, it is a sheath that action potential jumps over

item.title: neurons
item.description: membrane with ion channels negative inside ←→ positive outside controlled by [[sodium-potassium pump]] Three types of neurons sensory neurons get stimuli

item.title: nose
item.description: chemoreceptors found in the upper part of the nasal cavity (yellowish spot) water soluble volatile substances can be sensed (can dissolve in the mucus)

item.title: ossicles
item.description: small bones in the middle ear that intensify vibrations with a limit hammer, anvil, stirrup

item.title: ovaries
item.description: analogous to [[testicles]] 4x3x2cm [[gonads]] and endocrine glands too secretes estrogen and progesterone 500 eggs mature from 400 000

item.title: penis
item.description: copulatory organ to get sperm into the vagina 3 bodies with sinuses fill with blood and connective tissue (capsule) gives limit → hardening (erection)

item.title: peripheral nervous system
item.description: [[ganglions]], [[nerves]] [[autonomic nervous system]]

item.title: Pregnancy
item.description: lasts 40 weeks (38 weeks from conception) Conception/fertilization in the oviduct (14th day of menstrual cycle) the zygote dicides and travels a week into the uterus → begins [[implantation]]

item.title: prostate gland
item.description: under the bladder produce 25-28% of semen causes the semen’s alkaline pH (activates sperm) [!important] Components of semen unite in the prostate gland

item.title: receptors
item.description: sensitive for adequate [[stimulus]]

item.title: saccule
item.description: meaning:: zsákocska

item.title: scrotum
item.description: equals with the female [[labia]] regulates the temperature of [[testicles]] sperm cells need 34°C for maturation

item.title: semicircular canals
item.description: oriented in 3 directions

item.title: seminal vesicles
item.description: glands behind the bladder produce 70% of semen Seminal fluid contains… proteins, enzymes, vitamins, fructose (E for sperms)

item.title: skin
item.description: different [[receptors]] distributed unequally (richest in fingertips, lips) Mechanoreceptors sense touch, pressure, vibration Thermoreceptors different type for cold and warm

item.title: sodium-potassium pump
item.description: controls the flow of sodium (Na+) and potassium (K-) ions moves ion through changing its shape due to a phosphate from [[ATP]] → uses energy

item.title: stimulus
item.description: something that triggers a response in the body

item.title: Summary_Endocrine system
item.description: What is the task of the neuroendocrine system? (2p) maintenance of homeostasis Compare the 2 parts of the neuroendocrine system in 1 sentence!

item.title: Summary_Nervous system and sense
item.description: Why do neurons differ from other cells?(3p) Special membrane with [[sodium-potassium pump|ion channels]] → negative charge inside, positive outside excitable because of that

item.title: synapses
item.description: point of contact between [[neurons]]

item.title: taste buds
item.description: regenerate in about 5 days when burned

item.title: testicles
item.description: equal with female ovaries [[gonads]] and endocrine glands → produce 200-300 million immature sperm cells per day

item.title: thyroxine hormone disorders
item.description: underproduction during childhood → cretinism mental defects, big tongue, organ disfunction, lack of sexual maturation underproduction during adulthood (lack of iodine → hypothyroidism) poor appetite but weight gain, apathy, depression, bradycardia, constipation, hair loss, feeling cold, fatigue overproduction during adulthood → [[goitre]] big appetite but weight loss, high blood pressure, tachycardia, sweating, diarrhea, irritability, hyperactivity, bulging eyes

item.title: tongue
item.description: Chemoreceptors in [[taste buds]]. Same type in all places, only difference is the density. Can taste water soluble substances which dissolve in saliva.

item.title: Type 1
item.description: Type 1 autoimmune disease OR inflammation of pancreas from birth or childhood solution: diet + insulin injection

item.title: Type 2
item.description: Type 2 caused by unhealthy diet, lack of sports, age may cause: kidney failure, blindness, coma, limb amputation solutions: diet (+medicien)(+insulin)

item.title: umbilical cord
item.description: contains a thick artery and a vein

item.title: uterus
item.description: Two main parts of the uterus [[corpus of uterus]] [[cervix]]

item.title: utricle
item.description: meaning:: tömlőcske

item.title: vagina
item.description: [!info] This page does not exist (yet)!

item.title: vaginal opening
item.description: [!info] This page does not exist (yet)!

item.title: vas deferenses
item.description: store sperms during emission and pass them on

item.title: vestibular apparatus
item.description: [[semicircular canals]] sense rotational movement the [[utricle]] and [[saccule]] sense gravity and motion filled with fluid (movement of crytals)
